etymology.notes: Pan-Berber term found across all Amazigh varieties. One of the oldest attested Berber words.

usageNotes.text: Can refer to physical soil, land ownership, or homeland/country depending on context.
Akal holds deep cultural significance as connection to ancestral land is central to Amazigh identity.

translations.text: There is no land without water
Il n'y a pas de terre sans eau

etymology.notes: Universal across all Berber languages. The word is grammatically plural but can refer to any quantity of water.

usageNotes.text: Always takes plural agreement even when referring to a single body of water.

translations.text: eau de pluie (lit. eau du soleil)

definitions.meaning: sun; day (as a unit of time)

usageNotes.text: Can mean both the physical sun and a day as a time period.

etymology.notes: This word gives its name to the Adrar region in Mauritania and Adrar des Ifoghas in Mali.
Emphasizes political/cultural territory more than physical land (cf. akal).

usageNotes.text: While akal refers to physical land/soil, tamurt emphasizes the cultural and political sense of homeland or country.
Bread is central to Amazigh cuisine and culture. Traditional breads include tafarnout (flatbread) and various regional varieties.
Traditional Amazigh butter is often clarified and aged, giving it a distinct flavor used in cooking and as a condiment.
Olive cultivation is ancient in the Amazigh world. Olive oil (zzit n uzmmur) is a staple of the traditional diet.

etymology.notes: Related to the name 'Amawal' (dictionary). The root w-l is associated with speech and language across Berber.

usageNotes.text: Used with possessive suffixes to form reflexive pronouns: ixf-inu (myself), ixf-nnk (yourself), etc.
Traditionally, azgzaw covers both green and blue. Modern usage sometimes distinguishes blue with borrowed terms.
In Tachelhit, taddart can mean both a single house and a small village, reflecting the communal nature of Amazigh settlement.
Essential to oasis agriculture. The communal management of tirga is a cornerstone of Amazigh social organization.
Primarily refers to Eid al-Adha (the feast of sacrifice), one of the most important celebrations in Amazigh culture.
Collective granaries (iguddar) are icons of Amazigh architecture in southern Morocco. The city of Agadir takes its name from this word.
A communal space where grain is threshed after harvest. Often doubles as a gathering place for celebrations.
Tizi n'Test and Tizi n'Tichka are two of the most famous mountain passes in Morocco, both named with this Tamazight word.
One of the most emotionally significant words in Tamazight. Yemma carries deep cultural weight and respect.
Annual festivals combining religious pilgrimage with trade, music, and communal celebration. Central to Amazigh cultural life.
The traditional democratic decision-making body of Amazigh communities. Decisions require consensus.
The amghar leads by respect and consensus, not by force. The role is often rotational among families.
The staple bread baked in a traditional clay oven (tafarnawt). Breaking bread together is a sacred act of hospitality.
The word 'couscous' derives from the Berber. Friday couscous is a ritual meal shared with family and neighbors.
Endemic to southwestern Morocco. Women's cooperatives have long managed argan oil production—an ancient tradition now globally recognized.
Also used metaphorically for the entrance of a valley, cave, or building. Imi n'Ouadar means 'mouth of the valley.'
Yennayer (Amazigh New Year, January 13) marks the start of the agricultural calendar and is now an official holiday in Morocco.
The Barbary lion (izm n watlas) once roamed the Atlas Mountains. Though extinct in the wild, it remains a powerful symbol of Amazigh strength.
Essential working animal in mountain communities. Treated with respect in Amazigh culture.
Weaving is traditionally women's art in Amazigh culture. Each region has distinct patterns encoding identity, protection, and blessing.
Silver fibulae are key elements of Amazigh women's dress, with designs varying by region and carrying symbolic meaning.
A circular dance form where men and women perform together, accompanied by drums and group singing. Central to celebrations.
Similar to aḥidus but specific to the Souss and Anti-Atlas regions. Features call-and-response singing with complex rhythms.
A UNESCO-recognized instrument played exclusively by Tuareg women. The imzad accompanies poetry and storytelling.
A word of deep significance. Amazigh means 'free person' and tilelli is the state of being that defines Amazigh identity.
More than physical masculinity—encompasses honor, generosity, keeping one's word, and protecting the vulnerable.
The city of Ifrane in the Middle Atlas takes its name from the plural 'ifran' (caves).
Tislit n Unẓar (Bride of the Rain) is a rain ceremony where a doll is paraded through the village with songs requesting rainfall.
The Amazigh cultural movement (amussu amazigh) has been instrumental in achieving recognition of Tamazight as an official language.
The self-designation of the indigenous people of North Africa. Literally 'free person' — the very name encodes the value of freedom.
Became an official language of Morocco in 2011 alongside Arabic. Written in Tifinagh, Latin, and Arabic scripts.
One of the oldest alphabets in the world, with inscriptions dating back over 2,500 years. Still used by Tuareg communities and now standard in Moroccan schools.
Azrou, a town in the Middle Atlas, takes its name from this word.
Izrfan (plural) are the oral legal codes governing Amazigh communities. They cover water rights, land use, conflict resolution, and collective responsibility.
Often used metaphorically: 'tifawt n tamusni' — the light of knowledge.
Amarg is both a poetic genre and an emotional state — a deep longing that fuels artistic expression. Central to Tachelhit musical tradition.
Tanmirt is the standard expression of thanks across Tamazight varieties.
